question: Which of the following drugs has antipsychotic properties ?:
prompt:
Which of the following drugs has antipsychotic properties ?:A)Albendazole
B)Anastrozole
C)Aripiprazole
D)Cilostazol.
output0: Albendazole is an anti-parasitic drug that is sometimes used to treat psychotic symptoms in patients with neurocysticercosis, a parasitic infection of the central nervous system. While it does have antipsychotic properties, it is not a typical antipsychotic medication.
output1: Anastrozole is a drug used to treat certain types of cancer, such as breast cancer. It works by blocking the production of estrogen, which can slow the growth of cancer cells. However, it can also have antipsychotic effects, such as reducing agitation and aggression in some patients.
output2: Aripiprazole is an antipsychotic medication used to treat various psychiatric conditions, including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and major depressive disorder. It works by blocking the action of certain neurotransmitters in the brain, which helps to reduce symptoms of psychosis and improve mood.
output3: Cilostazol is an antipsychotic drug that is commonly used to treat psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia. It works by blocking the action of dopamine in the brain, which helps to reduce symptoms of psychosis.

question: 97 a 18-year-old woman, because the past few months that lower abdominal discomfort and medical treatment. Left side of her pelvic examination revealed a 10 cm large ovarian tumor, right ovary and normal uterine size. She underwent surgery to remove the tumor. This is visually observed that a gray solid tumors. Most tumors are visible under the microscope by the undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, cartilage cells or part of neuroepithelial differentiation. About this tumor narrative Which statement is correct?
options: B)Tumor cells derived from ovarian stromal cells
C)This tumor is often associated with endometrial hyperplasia
D)This tumor with the BRCA1 gene abnormalities
prompt:
97 a 18-year-old woman, because the past few months that lower abdominal discomfort and medical treatment. Left side of her pelvic examination revealed a 10 cm large ovarian tumor, right ovary and normal uterine size. She underwent surgery to remove the tumor. This is visually observed that a gray solid tumors. Most tumors are visible under the microscope by the undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, cartilage cells or part of neuroepithelial differentiation. About this tumor narrative Which statement is correct?
A)Is a malignant tumor
B)Tumor cells derived from ovarian stromal cells
C)This tumor is often associated with endometrial hyperplasia
D)This tumor with the BRCA1 gene abnormalities
output0: The tumor described is a malignant ovarian tumor, specifically a type known as a germ cell tumor. These tumors are derived from immature germ cells and are often associated with abnormalities in the BRCA1 gene. The presence of a large, gray solid tumor with undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, cartilage cells, or neuroepithelial differentiation is consistent with a malignant tumor.
output1: The tumor described in the scenario is a stromal tumor, which is a type of benign tumor that originates from the connective tissue of the ovary. The cells that make up the tumor are undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, which are not malignant. Therefore, the correct answer is B)Tumor cells derived from ovarian stromal cells.
output2: This type of tumor is often associated with endometrial hyperplasia, which is an abnormal growth of the endometrium (the lining of the uterus). The tumor is made up of undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, cartilage cells, or part of neuroepithelial differentiation, which are not typically found in ovarian tumors.
output3: The tumor described is a type of ovarian tumor called a borderline tumor. Borderline tumors are rare and are often associated with genetic mutations, such as those in the BRCA1 gene. The presence of a 10 cm large tumor, undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, and cartilage cells or neuroepithelial differentiation are all characteristics of a borderline tumor.

question: A 11 year old boy with grossly carious right maxillary lateral incisor, LA is given, complains of burning sensation in right eye, swelling in right eyelid, best statement to explain this condition.
correct_answer: Reaction is due to preservative in the L.A., it will subside in some time
options: A)Middle meningeal artery has tortuous course
B)LA reaches the eyelid via infraorbital foramen
C)Reaction is due to preservative in the L.A., it will subside in some time
D)Pain will subside in few minutes
prompt:
A 11 year old boy with grossly carious right maxillary lateral incisor, LA is given, complains of burning sensation in right eye, swelling in right eyelid, best statement to explain this condition.A)Middle meningeal artery has tortuous course
B)LA reaches the eyelid via infraorbital foramen
C)Reaction is due to preservative in the L.A., it will subside in some time
D)Pain will subside in few minutes
output0: The burning sensation in the right eye, swelling in the right eyelid, and pain in the right maxillary lateral incisor tooth are all symptoms of a dental infection, which is likely caused by the grossly carious tooth. The middle meningeal artery runs close to the infraorbital nerve, which supplies the eyelid and eye. The infection can cause swelling and inflammation in the tissues around the nerve, leading to the symptoms the patient is experiencing.
output1: The lacrimal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, passes through the infraorbital foramen and supplies blood to the eyelid. When the LA is placed in the right maxillary lateral incisor, it can cause a burning sensation in the right eye and swelling in the right eyelid due to the close proximity of the artery to the tooth.
output2: The burning sensation in the right eye, swelling in the right eyelid, and pain in the right maxillary lateral incisor are all common side effects of local anesthesia (LA) reactions. These symptoms are usually temporary and will subside within a short period of time, as the body metabolizes the preservative in the LA.
output3: The pain and swelling the boy is experiencing are likely due to the injection of the local anesthetic (LA) in the right maxillary lateral incisor. The burning sensation in the right eye is a common side effect of LA injection. The swelling in the right eyelid is due to the pressure of the anesthetic on the lacrimal gland. The pain and swelling will subside in a few minutes as the anesthetic wears off.

question: Which of the following traumatic events has a greater chance of leading to a Post Traumatic Stress Disorder ?:
options: D)A railway accident with multiple victims.
prompt:
Which of the following traumatic events has a greater chance of leading to a Post Traumatic Stress Disorder ?:A)An earthquake
B)A traffic accident.
C)A sexual assault
D)A railway accident with multiple victims.
output0: Earthquakes are often associated with widespread destruction, loss of life, and a sense of helplessness, which can increase the likelihood of developing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). Additionally, the sudden and unpredictable nature of earthquakes can make them more traumatic than other types of events.
output1: Traffic accidents are more likely to result in severe injuries and fatalities, which can lead to a higher risk of developing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). Additionally, the sudden and unexpected nature of traffic accidents can be particularly traumatic for those involved.
output2: A sexual assault is more likely to lead to Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) than other traumatic events, such as earthquakes, traffic accidents, or railway accidents with multiple victims. This is because sexual assault is a form of interpersonal trauma that can result in severe psychological and emotional harm, including feelings of fear, shame, guilt, and a sense of powerlessness. These feelings can be particularly distressing for the survivor and can have a profound impact on their mental health and well-being.
output3: Railway accidents with multiple victims have a greater chance of leading to Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) due to the severity of the trauma and the potential for multiple loss of life. Additionally, the sudden and unexpected nature of the event can lead to a sense of helplessness and lack of control, which can exacerbate the development of PTSD.

question: Upper lip is formed by the fusion of:
correct_answer: Maxillary, lateral nasal, median nasal process.
options: B)Lateral nasal and median nasal process.
C)Maxillary, lateral nasal, median nasal process.
D)Maxillary, mandibular, lateral nasal, median nasal process.
prompt:
Upper lip is formed by the fusion of:A)Maxillary and lateral nasal process.
B)Lateral nasal and median nasal process.
C)Maxillary, lateral nasal, median nasal process.
D)Maxillary, mandibular, lateral nasal, median nasal process.
output0: The upper lip is formed by the fusion of the maxillary and lateral nasal processes. This is a key structure in the formation of the face and mouth.
output1: The upper lip is formed by the fusion of the lateral nasal and median nasal processes of the maxilla bone.
output2: The upper lip is formed by the fusion of the maxillary, lateral nasal, and median nasal processes. This is a fundamental concept in embryology and is essential for understanding the development of the face and mouth.
output3: The upper lip is formed by the fusion of the maxillary, mandibular, lateral nasal, and median nasal processes. This is a fundamental concept in embryology and anatomy.

question: The earliest feature of 3rd cranial nerve involvement in diabetes mellitus patient is -
prompt:
The earliest feature of 3rd cranial nerve involvement in diabetes mellitus patient is -A)Normal light reflex
B)Abnormal light reflex
C)Normal light and accommodation reflex
D)Abnormal light and accommodation reflex
output0: The earliest feature of 3rd cranial nerve involvement in diabetes mellitus patients is normal light reflex. This is because the 3rd cranial nerve is responsible for controlling the light reflex in the eye, and diabetes mellitus patients may not experience any changes in this reflex until the disease has progressed to a more advanced stage.
output1: The earliest feature of 3rd cranial nerve involvement in diabetes mellitus patients is an abnormal light reflex. This is because the 3rd cranial nerve is responsible for controlling the pupillary light reflex, and diabetes can cause changes in the nerve that affect this reflex.
output2: In diabetes mellitus patients, the earliest feature of 3rd cranial nerve involvement is a normal light reflex, which is also known as the "turtle's eye" reflex. This reflex is a sign of autonomic nervous system dysfunction and can be an early indicator of diabetic neuropathy.
output3: The earliest feature of 3rd cranial nerve involvement in diabetes mellitus patients is abnormal light and accommodation reflex. This is because the 3rd cranial nerve is responsible for controlling the movement of the pupil and the accommodation of the eye, and diabetes mellitus can damage the nerve and cause abnormal reflexes.

question: Bernard-Soulier syndrome due to deficiency of
prompt:
Bernard-Soulier syndrome due to deficiency ofA)Gp 2b/3a
B)Gp 1b
C)vWf
D)TNF
output0: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the platelets and is caused by a deficiency of Gp 2b/3a, a protein that is essential for platelet function.
output1: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of platelet Gp 1b. This deficiency can lead to a range of symptoms, including easy bruising, petechiae, and prolonged bleeding.
output2: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of vWf, a protein that is essential for platelet function. It is characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding, bruising, and prolonged bleeding after trauma or surgery.
output3: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of Tissue Factor (TNF). TNF is a protein that plays a crucial role in the coagulation cascade.

question: Which of the following is unpaired bone of facial skeleton:
prompt:
Which of the following is unpaired bone of facial skeleton:A)Nasal
B)Lacrimal
C)Inferior nasal concha
D)Vomer
output0: The correct answer is A)Nasal because it is an unpaired bone of the facial skeleton. The nasal bone is a single bone that forms the bridge of the nose.
output1: The lacrimal bone is the only unpaired bone of the facial skeleton. The other bones of the facial skeleton are paired bones.
output2: The Inferior nasal concha is an unpaired bone of the facial skeleton. The other options (A) Nasal, (B) Lacrimal, and (D) Vomer are all paired bones.
output3: The vomer is an unpaired bone of the facial skeleton. It is a small bone that separates the nasal cavity from the oral cavity.

question: Which of the following has tumor promoting effect?
prompt:
Which of the following has tumor promoting effect?A)BRAC
B)RB
C)MYC
D)p16
output0: The BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are tumor suppressor genes that play a critical role in maintaining genomic stability. Mutations in these genes can lead to the development of breast and ovarian cancer. Therefore, the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes have a tumor-promoting effect.
output1: RB (Retinoblastoma) protein is a tumor suppressor that is inactivated in many types of cancer, including breast cancer. Inactivation of RB can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and cancer development.
output2: The MYC gene is a tumor-promoting gene that is overexpressed in many types of cancer. It plays a role in cell proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. Overexpression of MYC can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and the development of cancer.
output3: p16 is a tumor suppressor protein that inhibits the activity of CDK4/6, thereby preventing the progression of cells through the cell cycle. Overexpression of p16 can lead to cell cycle arrest and inhibit the growth of cancer cells. Therefore, p16 has a tumor-suppressing effect.

question: Which of the following is not derived from the external oblique aponeurosis?
prompt:
Which of the following is not derived from the external oblique aponeurosis?A)Inguinal Ligament
B)Lacunar ligament
C)Line Semilunaris
D)Pectineal Ligament
output0: The Inguinal Ligament is not derived from the external oblique aponeurosis. It is a ligament that holds the inguinal canal closed and is derived from the abdominal wall. The other options (Lacunar ligament, Linea semilunaris, and Pectineal ligament) are all derived from the external oblique aponeurosis.
output1: The Lacunar ligament is not derived from the external oblique aponeurosis. It is a ligament that connects the tendon of the rectus femoris muscle to the superior rim of the acetabulum.
output2: The Linea Semilunaris is not derived from the external oblique aponeurosis. It is a line of demarcation that separates the external oblique aponeurosis from the internal oblique aponeurosis.
output3: The Pectineal Ligament is not derived from the external oblique aponeurosis. It is a ligament that connects the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic bone.
